g.text: Do Not Cite, Quote or Distribute
C (SR15) made clear that the next three decades
are critical if we are to achieve the long
term mitigation goal of the Paris Agreement
The present Chapter assesses the literature o
n mitigation and development pathways over that
It considers three questions: (1) Where are we heading now? That is, what is the current state of affairs
with respect to climate mitigation an
d how did we get here? (2) Where do we want to go? I.e., what
the objectives of the Paris Agreement and achieving the S
? and (3) How do we bring about this shift? I.e., what interventions are a
societies’ disposal to bring about the necessary change in an equitable manner?
Despite the drop in emissions due to the COVID
between projected emissions based on Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) in
emissions pathways compatible with the long term temperature goal set in the Paris Agreement remains
large (4.2.2). In addition to this persistent emissions gap, we face an implementation gap, as current
policies are insufficient to achieve mitig
ation targets in NDCs, and sufficient international support is
not yet available to developing countries
who have requested and quantified support needs
along a development pathway characterized by the same underlying drivers, structural obstac
insufficient enabling conditions that led to high emissions will not address the problem (
The analysis of the gap is conducted together with Chapter 3 (see
term (beyond 2050 up to 2100) to draw the near
mitigations goals. Chapter 4, on the other hand,
works forward from current and planned mitigation (including NDCs) (4.2.1, 4.2.2) and from current
development paths to assess the implications for near
elopment goals. Some countries, regions, cities, communities and non
taking leadership in implementing more ambitious action (4.2.
Where do we want to go?
Technical alternatives and policy options exist to bridge the emissions and
implementation gaps, and the literature illustrates these with a wide range of accelerated techno
economic pathways that deepen decarbonisation closer to the pace and scale require
examines their impacts on other development objectives (4.2.6). In practice, however, scaling up at the
broader, deeper, and faster level required to meet climate goals while advancing other development
Mitigation policies grafted on to existing
development pathways are unlikely to achieve rapid and deep emission reductions.
Secondly, even if carefully designed, climate policies to accelerate mitigation may have adverse
or other development objectives. As a complement to mitigation action,
shift development pathways towards sustainability broadens the range of mitigation options, while
increasing the possibility to meet other development priorities at the
Development pathways and shifting them to increased sustainability are introduced in Chapter 1, and
constitute a thread throughout the report (see glossary
entry on development pathways). The WG
on shifting sustainable pathway towards sustainability elaborates on the concept. The
influence of development pathways on emissions and mi
tigative capacity is discussed in Chapter 2.
